awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Resolution Accurate-Mass Orbitrap LC-MS System at Montclair State University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Montclair State University is acquiring a benchtop high-resolution accurate-mass ultrahigh-pressure liquid chromatograph tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-MS/MS) system with an orbitrap analyzer to support Dr. Jinshan Gao and colleagues Meiyin Wu, Nina Goodey, Yang Deng and David Rotella. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex samples.  An instrument with a liquid chromatograph provides additional structural identification power by separating mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. The tandem capabilities, which couples together two mass analyzers, increase the ability of the mass spectrometer to analyze chemical samples. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at this Hispanic Serving Institution and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse students with this modern analytical technique. It is also used by collaborators at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, Fairleigh Dickinson University and Rutgers University.

The award of the UPLC-MS/MS (Ultra-high performance liquid chromatography/two dimensional mass spectrometry) system is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It is especially useful for quantifying and characterizing glycan, proteins and glycoproteins as well as identifying polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, cyanotoxin, lipids and biopolymers.  The instrumentation is also used for characterizing potential drug candidates and their metabolites and for the identification of and quantification of emerging contaminants and their transformation products in water and wastewater. The instrument also serves researchers characterizing genotoxic impurities in drug substances and other products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This system has been running smoothly and provides high-resolution mass spectrafor researchers at MSU and nearby institutions. This grant permits the purchase of a High-Resolution Accurate-Mass Orbitrap LC-MS System to strengthen research, hands-on education,and analytical training at Montclair State University. This system has been broadly used for characterization and
quantitation of glycan, protein, lipid, drug candidates, metabolites, and environmental emergingcontaminants with greater confidence. This system significantly enhances five PIs’ research supported by NSF, NIH, EPA,United State Geological Survey (USGS), US Department of Agriculture (USDA), NJDEP, VictoriaFoundation, and Landsberger Foundation Research.

Moreoer, the system has provided advanced analytical instrument training oppertunities for postdocs, doctoral and master students, and undergraduates from Chemistry, Biology, Earth andEnvironmental Studies, as well as high school interns supported by the American Chemical Society SEED program. Recognized as a Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI), Montclair State University is shaping the futures of Hispanic and Latine students by enhancing access and educational success. The PI strongly encourages the participation of groups underrepresented in science and engineering including women, African Americans, and Hispanic Americans. As a first-generation college student, the PI actively involves the participation of underrepresented minorities (URM) and first-generation students in his research.

This High-Resolution Accurate-Mass Orbitrap LC-MS System has been also incorporated to teaching portfolios of CHEM 490/590 Special Topics-Advanced Chemistry and CHEM 310 Analytical Chemistry. As an Analytical Chemistry professor in the Chemistry and Biochemistry Department at MSU, the PI primarily teaches these two analytical chemistry-related courses and is in charge of corresponding laboratory sections. CHEM 490/590 is a core course for senior undergraduate and graduate students in Chemistry, which covers all the advanced mass spectrometric techniques, including ionization, mass analyzer, mass detector, tandem mass spectrometry, GC/MS, LC/MS, and CE/MS. CHEM 310 is a core course for undergraduate students majoring in Chemistry and Biochemistry, wherein HPLC/MS-based internal standard, external standard, and standard addition methods are covered. The PI integrated this high resolution MS into these two analytical chemistry-related classes.


Last Modified: 10/29/2024
Modified by: Jinshan Gao
